name: Erdős #14: Unique Representation Sums
description: Given A ⊆ ℕ, let B be sums uniquely representable as a+b with a,b ∈ A. Questions: (a) Is |{1,...,N}\B| >> N^{1/2-ε} for all ε>0? (b) Can |{1,...,N}\B| = o(N^{1/2})?

insights: Problem concerns unique vs non-unique representations in sumsets
Sidon sets (B₂ sequences) have ALL sums unique, but are sparse (size O(√N))
Erdős constructed A with U(N) << N^{1/2+ε} for all large N
Same construction has U(N) >> N^{1/3-ε} infinitely often
Erdős-Freud: finite A ⊆ {1,...,N} can have U(N) < 2^{3/2}·√N
DeepMind formalized this using allUniqueSums and nonUniqueSumCount
Questions 14a and 14b are related: YES to 14a implies NO to 14b
